li.p: To understand that a one-parameter family of differential equations \frac{dx}{dt} = f_\lambda(x) has a bifurcation at \lambda = \lambda_0 if a change in the number or type of equilibrium solutions occurs.
To understand that bifurcation diagrams are an effective way of representing the nature of the solutions of a one-parameter family of differential equations.

introduction.p: Many of the equations that we have examined have a parameterparameter, which means that we actually have a family of differential equations. For example, \frac{dx}{dt} = kx has the growth rate parameter k. The logistic equation \frac{dP}{dt} = kP\left( 1 - \frac{P}{N} \right) has two parameters, k and N. In this section we will investigate how the solutions of a differential equation vary as we change the value of a parameter.

subsection.title: The Logistic Model with Harvesting Revisited
subsection.p: Recall how we modeled logistic growth in a trout pond in with the equation \frac{dP}{dt} = P\left(1 - \frac{P}{200} \right). If we allowed fishing in our pond at a rate of 32 fish per year, then the equation became \frac{dP}{dt} = P\left(1 - \frac{P}{200} \right) - 32. There are two equilibrium solutions for this equation, P_1 = 160 (a sink) and P_2 = 40 (a source). If the population of the pond falls below 40, then the fish will die out unless the pond is restocked or fishing is banned ().

image.description: a direction field of slope arrows with two curves approaching 160 and one curve aproaching zero
image.sageplot: k=1 N = 200 H = 32 P, t=var('P, t') p = plot_slope_field(k*P*(1 - P/N) - H, (t,-0,10), (P,0,200), headaxislength=3, headlength=3, axes_labels=['$t$','$P(t)$'], fontsize=12) p += desolve_rk4(k*P*(1 - P/N) - H,P,ics=[0,200],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[0, 10],thickness=2, color='blue') p += desolve_rk4(k*P*(1 - P/N) - H,P,ics=[0,100],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[0, 10],thickness=2, color='red') p += desolve_rk4(k*P*(1 - P/N) - H,P,ics=[0,39],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[0, 5.8],thickness=2, color='green') p

subsection.p: Now let us see what happens when we allow more fishing in our pond, say H = 100. Our differential equation now becomes \frac{dP}{dt} = P\left(1 - \frac{P}{200} \right) - 100. To determine the equilibrium solutions, we must solve \frac{dP}{dt} = P\left(1 - \frac{P}{200} \right) - 100 = 0 for P. This last equation can be rewritten as P^2 - 200P + 20000 = 0. Thus, P = \frac{200 \pm \sqrt{200^2 - 4 \cdot 20000}}{2} = 100 \pm \sqrt{-10000}, which means that equation has no real solutions and that we have no equilibrium solutions. Furthermore, dP/dt \lt 0 for all values of P. This means that no matter how many fish are in the pond initially, the trout population will eventually die out due to overfishing ().

image.description: a direction field of slope arrows with three curves decreasing to zero
image.sageplot: k=1 N = 200 H = 100 P, t=var('P, t') p=desolve_rk4(k*P*(1 - P/N) - H,P,ics=[0,150],ivar=t,output='slope_field',end_points=[0, 2.5],thickness=2, color='blue',axes_labels=['$t$','$P(t)$'], fontsize=12) q=desolve_rk4(k*P*(1 - P/N) - H,P,ics=[0,100],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[0, 1.55],thickness=2, color='red') r=desolve_rk4(k*P*(1 - P/N) - H,P,ics=[0,50],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[0, 0.65],thickness=2, color='green') p + q + r

subsection.p: Finally, we will let H = 50. In this case, we must solve \frac{dP}{dt} = P\left(1 - \frac{P}{200} \right) - 50 = 0 in order to determine any equilibrium solutions. We now obtain a single equilibrium solution at P = 100. In fact, P = 100 will be a node. For values of P \gt 100 as well as values of P \lt 100, we have dP/dt \lt 0, and the number of fish in the pond will decrease ().

image.description: a direction field of slope arrows with one curve decreasing towards one hundred and a horizontal line at one hundread and a curve the begins below one hundred and decreases
image.sageplot: k=1 N = 200 H = 50 N^2/4 - H*N/k P, t=var('P, t') p = plot_slope_field(k*P*(1 - P/N) - H, (t,0,20), (P,0,200), headaxislength=3, headlength=3, axes_labels=['$t$','$P(t)$'], fontsize=12) p += desolve_rk4(k*P*(1 - P/N) - H,P,ics=[0,200],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[0, 20],thickness=2, color='blue') p += desolve_rk4(k*P*(1 - P/N) - H,P,ics=[0,100],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[0, 20],thickness=2, color='red') p += desolve_rk4(k*P*(1 - P/N) - H,P,ics=[0,90],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[0, 18],thickness=2, color='green') p

subsection.p: To better understand what is happening, we will generalize our model. Suppose that a population with a limited carrying capacity N is modeled with the logistic equation \frac{dP}{dt} = kP\left(1 - \frac{P}{N}\right). If we allow harvesting at a constant rate H, our model now becomes \frac{dP}{dt} = kP\left(1 - \frac{P}{N}\right) - H. To analyze our model, we will first find the equilibrium solutions. If we will let f_H(P) = kP\left(1 - \frac{P}{N}\right) - H, each equilibrium solution must satisfy f_H(P) = 0 or -k P^2 + kNP - H N = 0. Therefore, our equilibrium solutions are given by P = \frac{-kN \pm \sqrt{k^2N^2 - 4kHN}}{-2k} = \frac{N}{2} \pm \sqrt{\frac{N^2}{4} - \frac{HN}{k}}.

The explanation of how our model behaves lies in the discriminant, \frac{N^2}{4} - \frac{HN}{k}. If \frac{N^2}{4} - \frac{HN}{k} \lt 0 or, equivalently if H \gt kN/4, there are no equilibrium solutions and \frac{dP}{dt} = f_H(P) \lt 0 for all values of P. In particular, all solutions of dP/dt = f_H(P) tend towards negative infinity as t \to \infty. In this case, the population is doomed to extinction no matter how large the initial population is. Since negative populations do not make sense, we say that the population is extinct when P = 0.

On the other hand, if H \lt kN/4, we have equilibrium solutions at P_1 =\frac{N}{2} + \sqrt{\frac{N^2}{4} - \frac{HN}{k}} and P_2 = \frac{N}{2} - \sqrt{\frac{N^2}{4} - \frac{HN}{k}}. The first equilibrium solution, P_1 is a sink, while the second, P_2 is a source.

Finally, if H = kN/4, then we will have exactly one equilibrium solution at P = N/2. Although dP/dt \lt 0 for all P \neq N/2, we see that P \to N/2 as t \to \infty for all initial values of P greater than N/2. For initial values of P less than N/2, solutions tend towards - \infty as t \to \infty. Thus, the initial population of fish must be at least kN/4; otherwise, the fish will go extinct.

In our example, we have a family of differential equationsone for each value of H, \frac{dP}{dt} = P\left( 1 - \frac{P}{200}\right) - H. A small change in H can have a dramatic effect on how the solutions of the differential equation behave. Changing the value of H from 50 to 50.1 will doom the population of fish to extinction no matter what the initial population is. As we increase the value of H, the number of equilibrium solutions changes from two to one and then to none. This change occurs exactly at H = 50. We say that a bifurcationbifurcation occurs at H = 50 for equation .

introduction.p: The chukar partridge, or simply chukar, is a upland gamebird in the pheasant family. Originally native to Asia and ranging from the eastern Mediterranean to Himalayas, the chukar has been widely introduced as an upland game bird with populations now established in the United States, Canada, Chile, Argentina, New Zealand and Hawaii. One particularly good area for hunting chukar is the western Great Basin area of the U.S. (eastern Oregon and Washington and western Idaho).

statement.p: Suppose that the population of chukar on a private game ranch in eastern Oregon grows logisitically. Estimates tell us that the one hundred square mile ranch and that the ranch can support at most 120 birds per square mile. The growth rate of the chukar population is estimated to be 1.5 birds per year. Model the growth of the chukar population with an initial value problem.

Suppose that hunting on the ranch is restricted to guests and the average guest harvest 10 chukars per visit. Modify the model in part (a) to take into account the effect that hunting has on the chukar population.
What is the maximum number of guests that the ranch can accommodate and still maintain a healthy population of game birds? How many chukar per square mile would be needed to allow this many guests?

subsection.title: One-Parameter Families
subsection.p: Let us consider the equation \frac{dx}{dt} = x^2 - 4x + \lambda as a family of differential equations indexed by the parameter \lambda. If we let f_\lambda(x) = x^2 - 4x + \lambda, then \frac{dx}{dt} = f_\lambda(x) is a called one-parameter familydifferential equationone-parameter family of differential equations. For each value of \lambda, we obtain an autonomous differential equation, and for each value of \lambda, we have a different phase line to examine.
For \lambda = 0, the differential equation \frac{dx}{dt} = f_0(x) = x^2 - 4x = x(x-4), there is a sink at x = 0 and a source at x = 4 ().

image.description: a direction field of slope arrows with three curves with the curve starting above two approaching infinity and the two curves starting below two approaching zero
image.sageplot: lam=0 x, t = var('x, t') v = plot_slope_field(x^2 - 4*x + lam, (t,-4,4), (x,-2,6), headaxislength=3, headlength=3, axes_labels=['$t$','$x(t)$'], fontsize=14, aspect_ratio=1) p=desolve_rk4(x^2 - 4*x + lam,x,ics=[-4,3],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[-4, 4],thickness=2, color='blue') q=desolve_rk4(x^2 - 4*x + lam,x,ics=[-4,4.1],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[-4,-3.33],thickness=2, color='red') r=desolve_rk4(x^2 - 4*x + lam,x,ics=[-4,-1.9],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[-4, 4],thickness=2, color='green') lam0 = text("$\lambda = 0$",(2,2), fontsize=14) lam0_plot = p + q + r + v + lam0 lam0_plot

subsection.p: For \lambda = 4, the differential equation \frac{dx}{dt} = f_4(x) = x^2 - 4x + 4 = (x - 2)^2, we have exactly one equilibrium solution, a node at x = 2 ().

image.description: a direction field of slope arrows with two curves with the curve starting above two approaching infinity and the two curves starting below two approaching two
image.sageplot: lam=4 x, t = var('x, t') p = plot_slope_field(x^2 - 4*x + lam, (t,-4,4), (x,-2,6), headaxislength=3, headlength=3, axes_labels=['$t$','$x(t)$'], fontsize=12, aspect_ratio=1) p += desolve_rk4(x^2 - 4*x + lam,x,ics=[-4,2.12],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[-4, 4],thickness=2, color='blue') p += desolve_rk4(x^2 - 4*x + lam,x,ics=[-4,2],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[-4,4],thickness=2, color='red') p += desolve_rk4(x^2 - 4*x + lam,x,ics=[-4,-1.9],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[-4, 4],thickness=2, color='green') p += text("$\lambda = 4$",(2,1), fontsize=12) p

subsection.p: If \lambda = 8, then the differential equation \frac{dx}{dt} = f_8(x) = x^2 - 4x + 8 has no equilibrium solutions ().

image.description: a direction field of slope arrows with three curves with each curve approaching infinity
image.sageplot: lam = 8 x, t=var('x, t') p = plot_slope_field(x^2 - 2*x + mu, (t,-4,4), (x,-4,4), headaxislength=3, headlength=3, axes_labels=['$t$','$x(t)$'], fontsize=12, aspect_ratio=1) p += desolve_rk4(x^2 - 2*x + mu,x,ics=[-4,1],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[-4,-2.75],thickness=2, color='blue') p += desolve_rk4(x^2 - 2*x + mu,x,ics=[-2,-4],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[-2, 0.64],thickness=2, color='red') p += desolve_rk4(x^2 - 2*x + mu,x,ics=[2,-4],ivar=t,output='plot',end_points=[2,4],thickness=2, color='green') p += text("$\mu = 2$",(2,2), fontsize=12) p

subsection.p: In fact, the number of equilibrium solutions for changes at \lambda = 4. We say that \lambda = 4 is a bifurcation valuebifurcationbifurcation value for the differential equation \frac{dx}{dt} = f_\lambda(x) = x^2 - 4x + \lambda. For \lambda \lt 4, we have two equilibrium solutions. x = 2 \pm \sqrt{4 - \lambda}. For values of \lambda \gt 4, there are no equilibrium solutions. We can record all of the information for the various values in a graph called the bifurcation diagrambifurcationdiagram. The horizontal axis is \lambda and the vertical axis is x. Over each value of \lambda, we will plot the corresponding phase line. The curve in the graph represents the various equilibrium solutions for the different values of \lambda. The bifurcation diagram for equation is a parabola (). We have a phase line for each value of \lambda.

image.description: a parabola with the vertex to the right and opening to the left and the parabola intersected by vertical lines with each line indicating where the solution increases and decreases
image.sageplot: t = var('t') p = parametric_plot( (-t*(t-4), t), (t, -1/4, 17/4), thickness = 2, axes_labels=['$\lambda$','$x$'], fontsize=12) p += line([(1,-1),(1,5)], color="red") + circle((1,2-sqrt(3)), 0.07, fill = true, color="red") + circle((1,2+sqrt(3)), 0.07, fill = true, color="red") + arrow2d((1, -1), (1, -0.5), arrowsize = 3, color='red', width = 1) + arrow2d((1, 1), (1, 4.5), arrowsize = 3, color='red', width = 1) + arrow2d((1, 3), (1, 2), arrowsize = 3, color='red', width = 1) p += line([(2,-1),(2,5)], color="red") + circle((2,2-sqrt(2)), 0.07, fill = true, color="red") + circle((2,2+sqrt(2)), 0.07, fill = true, color="red") + arrow2d((2, -1), (2, -0.5), arrowsize = 3, color='red', width = 1) + arrow2d((2, 1), (2, 4.5), arrowsize = 3, color='red', width = 1) + arrow2d((2, 3), (2, 2), arrowsize = 3, color='red', width = 1) p += line([(3,-1),(3,5)], color="red") + circle((3,1), 0.07, fill = true, color="red") + circle((3,3), 0.07, fill = true, color="red") + arrow2d((3, -1), (3, -0.5), arrowsize = 3, color='red', width = 1) + arrow2d((3, 1), (3, 4.5), arrowsize = 3, color='red', width = 1) + arrow2d((3, 3), (3, 2), arrowsize = 3, color='red', width = 1) p += line([(4,-1),(4,5)], color="red") + circle((4,2), 0.07, fill = true, color="red") + arrow2d((4, -1), (4, -0.5), arrowsize = 3, color='red', width = 1) + arrow2d((4, 1), (4, 4.5), arrowsize = 3, color='red', width = 1) p += line([(5,-1),(5,5)], color="red") + arrow2d((5, 1), (5, 2), arrowsize = 3, color='red', width = 1) p

subsection.p: Bifurcations for a one-parameter family of differential equations dx/dt = f_\lambda(x) are, in fact, rare. Let us consider a bifurcation where a sink changes to a source as we vary the parameter \lambda. Suppose that for \lambda = \lambda_0, we have a sink at x_0. Then \frac{dx}{dt} = f_{\lambda_0}(x_0) = 0. Furthermore, the graph of f_{\lambda_0}(x) must be decreasing for x near x_0, since f_{\lambda_0}(x) must be postive for values of x \lt x_0 and negative for values of x \gt x_0. In other words, f'_{\lambda_0}(x) \lt 0 for x near x_0 with f'_{\lambda_0}(x_0) \lt 0, then for all \lambda_1 sufficiently close to \lambda_0, the differential equation \frac{dx}{dt} = f_{\lambda_1}(x) must have sink at a point x = x_1 very close to x_0. A similar situation holds if x_0 is a source and f'_{\lambda_0}(x_0) \gt 0. Thus, bifurcations can only occur when f_{\lambda_0}(x_0) = 0 and f'_{\lambda_0}(x_0) = 0.

example.p: Now consider the one-parameter family \frac{dy}{dt} = y^3 - \alpha y = y (y^2 - \alpha). We will have an equilibrium solution at zero for all values of \alpha and two additional equilibrium solutions at \pm \sqrt{\alpha} for \alpha \gt 0. This type of bifurcation is a pitch fork bifurcationbifurcationpitch fork ().

example.p: Let us find the bifurcation values of the one-parameter family \frac{dy}{dt} = y(y - 2)^2 + \lambda. If g_\lambda(y) = y(y - 2)^2 + \lambda, then g'_\lambda(y) = 3y^2 - 8y + 4. The roots of g'_\lambda(y) = 0 are y = 2 and y = 2/3. In order for \lambda to be a bifurcation value, we must have g_\lambda(2) = \lambda = 0 or g_\lambda(2/3) = \frac{32}{27} + \lambda = 0 Thus, equation has two bifurcation values, \lambda = -32/27 and \lambda = 0. The bifurcation diagram for this one-parameter family is given in .

ul.li: A one-parameter family of differential equations \frac{dx}{dt} = f_\lambda(x) has a bifurcation at \lambda = \lambda_0 if a change in the number of equilibrium solutions occurs.
Bifurcation diagrams are an effective way of representing the nature of the solutions of a one-parameter family of differential equations.
Bifurcations for a one-parameter family of differential equations dx/dt = f_\lambda(x) are rare. Bifurcations occur when f_{\lambda_0}(x_0) = 0 and f'_{\lambda_0}(x_0) = 0.
